<<level 2>> Cancer-Associated Thrombosis: Who Is at Risk?

• Separating cancer into subcategories of patients who can or are likely to get blood clots vs those who are not likely to get blood clots is key • A single risk factor does not predict the full assessment of risk in this population

<<insert slide 4>>

<<level 2>>Cancer-Associated Thrombosis: How to Identify Those at Risk [1]

• Surveys suggest that cancer patients are very unware of the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) • They are very aware of becoming nauseated, having emesis, and getting infections and when to report these problems • They are not aware of leg swelling or increased shortness of breath or sudden onset of chest pain as being concerning • Providers must assess the risk, have a discussion, and educate patients about warning signs and symptoms of VTE <<insert slide 5>>

<<level 2>> Study Results[5,6]

• In both those trials, the non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs) were better in terms of reducing the risk of recurrent VTE with some increase in bleeding • Both trials assessed the 6-month time point o The Hokusai study extended to 12 months, but for most patients the median time was around 6 months

<<insert slide 12>>

<<level 2>>LMWH and VKAs[7]

• The advantage of low-molecular heparin vs vitamin K antagonist (VKA) is that you can titrate the dose • If, for example, a patient presents with gastrointestinal bleeding (GI), a lower dose can be used to start and then the dose can be gradually increased when bleeding ceases • Or, if a patient develops thrombocytopenia, you can titrate the dose down and ramp it back up again as the platelet count recovers • There is a flexibility in dosing, which is not seen with VKAs o VKAs are only effective when the international normalized ratio (INR) is between 2 and 3, and that is difficult to maintain <<insert slide 13>>

<<level 2>>Study Results (cont)[5,6]

• Hokusai VTE Cancer and SELECT-D studies had similar results • Bleeding was seen especially in patients with GI cancer • There are now broader options for anticoagulation to manage thrombosis in our cancer patients <<insert slide 14>>

<<level 2>> Patient Persistence with Anticoagulant: LMWH vs Oral Agents[8]

• Consistently in studies looking at different populations -- older patients, younger patients, patients with private insurance, patients with Medicare -- the results are the same o Persistence on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is much lower than persistence on any oral agent, including VKAs • There is clearly a limitation of prolonged parenteral therapy that needs to be borne in mind

<<insert slide 15>>

<<level 2>> Challenges of Anticoagulation Therapy

• In the Hokusai VTE Cancer study, for example, only about 11% of the patients had hematological malignancies; thrombocytopenia was not a big issue • In patents with lymphoma or leukemia, thrombocytopenia becomes a major challenge • If anticoagulants are stopped, the risk of reoccurrence is at least around 20% in that first year[9] <<insert slide 16>>

<<level 2>> Ottawa Risk Score[10]

• The Ottawa score has not been validated in every study • It is very good at predicting low-risk patients, but not so good at predicting high-risk patients • The other challenge is all of these risk assessment tools were developed in the LMWH era
